definition[0]: the process of finding out what people think about something by asking many people the same question, or the record of the result
example[0]: A recent poll found that 80% of Californians support the governor.
example[1]: Polls indicate that education is the top issue with voters.
example[2]: Labour is ahead in the polls.
example[3]: The latest public opinion poll showed that 25% of us consider ourselves superstitious.
definition[1]: the process of voting in an election, or the number of votes recorded
example[7]: Labour won the election with 40% of the poll.
example[8]: The result of the poll won’t be known until around midnight.
example[9]: A similar poll was carried out among academics in the United States.
example[10]: A poll taken last month gave the Democrats a seven-point lead.
example[11]: The poll was conducted with a sample of 1,023 adults.
example[12]: Polls show that older voters are most concerned about economic issues.
example[13]: Our poll found that 29 percent rated his performance as good.
example[14]: The poll results are very encouraging.
example[16]: A recent opinion poll showed strong support for the government.
example[17]: The exit polls said that 46 percent of women had voted for Obama.
example[18]: In most popularity polls, he is in fourth or fifth place.
example[19]: Local polls show him leading by only two or three points.
example[20]: Labour soon regained its lead in the polls.
example[21]: The president's standing in the polls declined sharply.
example[22]: The good news is that we are ahead in the polls.
example[23]: At the moment the Democrats are trailing in the polls.
definition[2]: to ask a lot of people the same questions in order to find out what they think about a subject
example[24]: 18% of the women we polled said their husbands had a drinking problem.
definition[3]: to get a particular number of votes in an election
example[25]: Labour polled just 4% of the vote.
definition[4]: an occasion when a large number of people are asked questions, to find out about the public’s opinions or behaviour
example[26]: MORIconducted a poll among senior managers to get their views on taxation.
example[27]: A recentopinion poll put him in third place.
example[28]: According to our poll, Scandinavians buy shares more than other Europeans.
definition[5]: an election to choose a government or a political representative
example[29]: The ruling Social Democrats suffered their worst defeat at the polls in 60 years.
example[30]: In Oklahoma, voters may go to the polls (=vote in an election) as early as September.
definition[6]: an occasion when the members of a company vote for or against something in a meeting
example[31]: Both directors were elected after a poll of shareholders.
definition[7]: the number of votes recorded at an election
example[32]: The winning party must gain at least 50% of the poll.
definition[8]: to try to find out about the public’s behaviour or opinions by questioning a large number of people
example[33]: 47% of office workers polled said that eye strain was a serious concern.
